results.title: Rude awakening
results.creator_credit: David Greenwalt, Aaron Russo and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Rude awakening is just that, when hippies Hesus and Fred return to New York after spending twenty years at a hippie commune in Central America, they find that things have not stayed the same and are in for one awakening they did not expect. They return to New York armed with Government papers that fell into their hands informing them of a proposed war in Central America. Needing the help and support of their old friends, they soon find they have changed from the once youthful free spirited drug taking hippies, to the uptight hard nosed yuppies that they used to despise. “Rude awakening” looks at the environmental challenges our world faces and the reluctance by people to stand up and express their anger and objection to the destruction of a highly delicate world in which we live. Cast includes Eric Roberts, Cheech Marin, Robert Carradine and Julie Hagerty.

results.title: The Grinch
results.creator_credit: Ron Howard, Brian Grazer and Universal Studios
results.brief_description: In Whoville, the Whos are overexcited, preparing for both Christmas, and the town’s ‘Whobelation’, a celebration of everything ‘Who’. The Grinch (Jim Carrey), living on Mount Crumpet overlooking the town of Whoville, despises everything about the holiday season and the town (due to a bad childhood Christmas experience) and decides to stop the festive season all together. Meanwhile, down in Whoville little Cindy Lou Who is trying to discover the true meaning behind Christmas and believes the Grinch might have the answers. A live-action adaptation of Dr. Seuss’s Christmas classic ‘How the Grinch Stole Christmas’, narrated by Anthony Hopkins. Cast also includes Molly Shannon, Christine Baranski, Bill Irwin and Jeffrey Tambor.

results.title: Unhook the stars
results.creator_credit: Nick Cassavetes, Panos Nicolaou, Rene Cleitman and Hachette Premiere
results.brief_description: Gena Rowlands portrays a middle-aged widow whose life is on the threshold of change. Her daughter has just left home on less than amicable terms and her married son is totally absorbed in his own life. When Mildred is approached by her neighbour (Marissa Tomei) to mind her young son, JJ, after her abusive husband walks out, she immediately consents. Initially quiet and tentative, JJ gradually gains confidence as the two develop a strong bond which provides them with the support they lack from their own families. The film explores the evolving relationship between Mildred and her two children, contrasting it to the unconditional friendship she shares with JJ. Cast includes Gena Rowlands, Marisa Tomei, Gerard Depardieu and Jake Lloyd. Edited by Petra Von Oelffen. Photographed by Phedon Papamichael. Written by Nick Cassavetes and Helen Caldwell.

results.brief_description: Light years ahead of it’s time, Kubrick’s masterpiece has an awesome scope - his special effects border on miraculous. Inspired by Arthur C. results.title: Death of a salesman [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Volker Schlondorff, Robert F. Colesberry and Roxbury and Punch
results.brief_description: This play, written by Arthur Miller, is one of the enduring glories of the American theatre. This adaptation was filmed within the confines of a Broadway stage set, thereby enhancing the intimacy of the study of the disintegration of the travelling salesman. Flashbacks are adroitly interwoven with the current scenes, providing a build-up to the shattering climax. Cast includes Dustin Hoffman and John Malkovich.

results.title: Man of marble = Czlowiek z marmuru [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Andrzej Wajda, Film Polski and Zespol Filmowy 'X'
results.brief_description: Lauded a national hero in the 1950s due to his skills at his trade, Mateusz Birkut has fallen into the shadows. In making a film of the bricklayer’s life, documentary director Krystyna Janda discovers that he used his fame to become involved in politics - resulting in the government wiping out all traces of his accomplishments. Excised by the Polish censors when first released, ‘Man of marble’ uses reconstructions of old black and white newsreels and matches the stylistic tenets of the documentary genre. (Awards: Winner of the FIPRESCI award, Cannes Film Festival, 1978). In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: Cookie's fortune
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, Etchie Stroh and Kudzu Productions
results.brief_description: Cookie, an eccentric old woman with a sizeable fortune, lives in a grand old home in Holly Springs, Mississippi. Contrary to the ‘good taste’ of her niece, the uppity Camille, Cookie lives in an un-conventional, disorderly manner: she wears T-shirts with antique jewellery, smokes pipes, plays crosswords, and, worst of all, is best friends with a black man, Willis, who lives with her and takes care of her. Though Cookie’s remaining family members are close by, she rarely enjoys their company: her niece Camille is haughty and disapproving, her daughter Cora seemingly catatonic and her feisty, independent granddaughter, Emma, has just returned after a long absence. Cookie instead longs profoundly for her dead husband. On one fine day, she takes dramatic action to be reunited with him, an act that disrupts the town and brings into view the divergent attitudes and personalities that populate this small American town. “Cookie’s Fortune” is a Southern gothic comedy that, like Altman’s previous films, interconnects multiple characters to paint a portrait of society at large. The subtlest of his films, “Cookie’s Fortune” focuses on a small American town to juxtapose the ‘old racist South’ with the ‘new South’ in which interracial relationships and carefree attitudes have replaced the repression and stoicism of the past. Though there is a hint of narrative suspense, “Cookie’s Fortune” proceeds with a higher purpose: taking a relaxed, meandering pace to trace out the moral dimensions of its milieu, and the potential for art to encourage pretension and superficiality while affirming that the joy of life is offered to those who embrace it by way of being earthly, honest, good-natured and spirited. Cast includes Glenn Close, Charles S Dutton, Chris O’Donnell, Liv Tyler, Julianne Moore, Patricia Neal, Ned Beatty, Lyle Lovett.

results.title: Malcolm [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Nadia Tass, David Parker and Cascade Films
results.brief_description: Malcolm, a simple genius played by Colin Friels, loses his job at a Melbourne tram depot after building his own one-man tram and taking to the streets. With funds dwindling, Malcolm is forced to take in a lodger, a small time criminal who moves in with girlfriend, Judith. Frank soon realizes that Malcolm’s mechanical wizardry can help his career - the result - a series of oddball but unsuccessful robberies that culminates in the heist of the decade that stretches Malcolm’s devises to the full. “Malcolm” was critically acclaimed world wide and received eight AFI Awards including best director and best film.

results.title: Innocence
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Mark Patterson, Cinemedia Corporation, New Oz Productions, Premium Movie Partnership, South Australian Film Corporation and Strand
results.brief_description: Paul Cox’s “Innocence” is a tender meditation on life and love at old age. Charles “Bud” Tingwell plays Andreas, an elderly widow who is undergoing a reflective period in his life marked by clarity and melancholy. A sentimental, rather impetuous man, Andreas longs for the woman he had a fleeting though passionate affair with over 40 years ago. “Innocence” begins with the re-encounter of Andreas and Claire (Julia Blake) and traces their flowering love and deep mutual affection. It’s a reunion that reawakens a love which has laid dormant for many years and that turns them both into young lovers: they become nervous before their first sexual encounter; they long for each other’s company at every moment afterward. In fact, their love is like a ‘time travel’ experience with flashbacks emphasising the entwinement of past and present. It is rare to see a film so devoted to the elderly and their affairs of the heart. Cox also manages to outline the complexities involved. For example, Claire’s new love poses serious problems for her marriage, and forces both herself and her husband, John (Terry Norris), to question their 45-year commitment. “Innocence” is ultimately a story about love, its different forms, its both destructive potential and ecstatic power.

results.title: The End of violence
results.creator_credit: Wim Wenders, Deepak Nayar, Nicholas Klein, Ciby Pictures, Kintop Pictures and Road Movies
results.brief_description: Mike Max (Bill Pullman) is a leading Hollywood producer, whose triumph has come from a string of extremely violent action films. His work is his life, and he neglects his wife Paige (Andie MacDowell) in his pursuit of success. Paige, frustrated with his lack of attention, leaves him, and Max is forced to admit he was a less-than supportive husband. Not long after, Max becomes involved in a violent killing, and fearing for his life, goes into hiding, falling victim to a new top-secret surveillance system, which caught the crime on camera. Escaping into L.A.’s underworld, Max confronts a violence more terrifying than anything he could put on film. Directed by Wim Wenders (Wings of desire; Faraway so close; Paris, Texas) ‘The End of Violence’ is a tale of conspiracy, the effects of violence in our culture, and personal transformation. Cast includes Traci Lind, Rosiland Chao, Gabriel Byrne, Udo Kier, Frederic Forrest and director Samuel Fuller. The film’s score was composed by Ry Cooder.
